articles.headline: Gunman in Munich Kills 9, Then Himself, the Police Say
articles.snippet: The police said the attack outside a mall was probably the work of a single gunman. At least 21 people were wounded.
articles.abstract: The police said the attack outside a mall was probably the work of a single gunman. At least 21 people were wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — A gunman opened fire outside a shopping mall in Munich late on Friday afternoon, killing nine people, wounding 21 and sending Germany’s third-largest city into lockdown as the police scrambled to find what they initially thought were as many as three assailants.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi, Melissa Eddy and Andrew Jacobs

articles.headline: With Roger Ailes Out, Will Fox News’s Influence on Politics Change?
articles.snippet: In its 20 years, the network has provided a path for Republican politicians and candidates to raise issues, set agendas and shape opinions.
articles.abstract: In its 20 years, the network has provided a path for Republican politicians and candidates to raise issues, set agendas and shape opinions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Donald J. Trump wanted to proclaim his doubts about President Obama’s birth certificate, he went to Fox News.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Journey: From Crashing a Party to Controlling Its Future
articles.snippet: It is hard to imagine the Republican Party returning anytime soon to being the party of free trade, democracy building and at least modest immigration reform.
articles.abstract: It is hard to imagine the Republican Party returning anytime soon to being the party of free trade, democracy building and at least modest immigration reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Donald J. Trump and the army of voters he brought into politics, overpowering all attempts at dissent, have pushed through fundamental changes in the Republican Party, many of which seem likely to endure whether or not he wins the White House in November.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Payday Loan Limits May Cut Abuse but Leave Some Borrowers Looking
articles.snippet: Lenders and some consumer advocates ask what borrowers will do if stricter regulations remove their main source of short-term financial aid.
articles.abstract: Lenders and some consumer advocates ask what borrowers will do if stricter regulations remove their main source of short-term financial aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ohio — This city of 73,000 is known for a few things — the Pro Football Hall of Fame, the presidential library of William McKinley, a lively downtown arts scene.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Selects Tim Kaine, a Popular Senator From a Swing State, as Running Mate
articles.snippet: Mr. Kaine, a former governor of Virginia who is now on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, speaks fluent Spanish and has a strong friendship with Mrs. Clinton.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kaine, a former governor of Virginia who is now on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, speaks fluent Spanish and has a strong friendship with Mrs. Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick, Alan Rappeport and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Tim Kaine: A Self-Effacing Senator in a Sharp-Elbows Era
articles.snippet: Mr. Kaine, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, a senator and former governor of Virginia, is known for his calm temperament, willingness to build bridges and Catholic faith.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kaine, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, a senator and former governor of Virginia, is known for his calm temperament, willingness to build bridges and Catholic faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after Barack Obama became the first African-American to win the White House, Tim Kaine, then the governor of Virginia, visited a civil rights memorial in Richmond. There, in a former capital of the Confederacy, he summed up the history-making moment in four words.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: They Promised Us Jet Packs. They Promised the Bosses Profit.
articles.snippet: Alphabet’s X research lab is still being asked to imagine the impossible. Only now, under pressure from investors, it has to imagine making money, too.
articles.abstract: Alphabet’s X research lab is still being asked to imagine the impossible. Only now, under pressure from investors, it has to imagine making money, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Project Foghorn is one of those straight-from-science-fiction concepts we’ve come to expect from Alphabet, the sprawling conglomerate formerly known as Google. The idea, hatched by the company’s X research lab, was to use seawater and chemistry to create fuel that could be refined into gasoline. This gas would be just like the gas we fill our cars with today — except that unlike today’s gas, it would not add to global warming because it would recycle carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Munich Killer Was Troubled, but Had No Terrorist Ties, Germany Says
articles.snippet: The motivations of the gunman, an 18-year-old dual German-Iranian citizen, remained unclear. He had been treated for depression and complained of being bullied.
articles.abstract: The motivations of the gunman, an 18-year-old dual German-Iranian citizen, remained unclear. He had been treated for depression and complained of being bullied.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — He had been bullied at more than one school. He played violent video games, and developed a fascination with mass shootings. He kept a copy of the German edition of “Why Kids Kill: Inside the Minds of School Shooters,” a study by an American academic psychologist, and he was treated for psychiatric problems.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine Debut Ticket in Battleground of Florida
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton appeared with Mr. Kaine in Miami, who peppered his remarks with Spanish in a bid to woo Hispanic voters in the swing state of Florida.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton appeared with Mr. Kaine in Miami, who peppered his remarks with Spanish in a bid to woo Hispanic voters in the swing state of Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Hillary Clinton debuted her running mate, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, to boisterous and bilingual cheers here on Saturday, calling him a “progressive who likes to get things done” even as some liberal Democrats began making clear that they were disappointed with her choice.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: A Hollywood Start-Up Sees New Life in Dead Movie Scripts
articles.snippet: With the coming release of “Coin Heist,” Adaptive Studios will test its idea of turning neglected Hollywood scripts into books and movies.
articles.abstract: With the coming release of “Coin Heist,” Adaptive Studios will test its idea of turning neglected Hollywood scripts into books and movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The forthcoming film “Coin Heist” — the tale of four prep-school students who try to rob the United States Mint — will present the first big test of a new studio with an unusual business model.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: A Profit Bump for Companies, and Tax Transparency for Investors
articles.snippet: A shift in the way companies deduct stock options will raise reported net earnings, but it could also rekindle a debate about low U.S. corporate taxes.
articles.abstract: A shift in the way companies deduct stock options will raise reported net earnings, but it could also rekindle a debate about low U.S. corporate taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think the world of accounting is dull? Then you don’t know about the new auditing rule that is about to raise many companies’ reported profits and bring greater clarity to the actual taxes big corporations pay.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: On Death Penalty Cases, Tim Kaine Revealed Inner Conflict
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s running mate fervently opposed capital punishment, but carried it out 11 times as governor of Virginia, while granting clemency only once.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton’s running mate fervently opposed capital punishment, but carried it out 11 times as governor of Virginia, while granting clemency only once.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kevin Green’s lawyers were pleading with the governor for mercy.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: At Fox News, Kisses, Innuendo, Propositions and Fears of Reprisal
articles.snippet: Current and former employees describe instances of sexual harassment and intimidation, suggesting that Roger Ailes’s exit may not be the end of the network’s woes.
articles.abstract: Current and former employees describe instances of sexual harassment and intimidation, suggesting that Roger Ailes’s exit may not be the end of the network’s woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2006, after nearly a decade at CNN, Rudi Bakhtiar came to the Fox News Channel’s headquarters in New York with a command of foreign policy, an appealing personality and a delivery that easily switched between light and serious.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Emily Steel and John Koblin

articles.headline: One Police Shift: Patrolling an Anxious America
articles.snippet: Riding along with officers illuminated fears they confront, compassionate gestures from the public after two recent ambushes against the police, and varied responses to the Black Lives Matter movement.
articles.abstract: Riding along with officers illuminated fears they confront, compassionate gestures from the public after two recent ambushes against the police, and varied responses to the Black Lives Matter movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Policing in America today is a rib dinner paid for by a stranger, and a protester kicking a dent into your patrol car door. It’s warning a young man speeding down a country road to beware of errant deer, and searching through trash cans for a gun on the streets of a big city.
articles.byline: By The New York Times

articles.headline: Migrants and Smugglers Won’t Be Stopped by Donald Trump’s Wall, Ranchers Say
articles.snippet: Ranchers near the Mexican border see smugglers and sometimes find bodies, but they favor a different approach to illegal immigration from Donald J. Trump’s wall.
articles.abstract: Ranchers near the Mexican border see smugglers and sometimes find bodies, but they favor a different approach to illegal immigration from Donald J. Trump’s wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: NACO, Ariz. — John Ladd has two old pickups he uses to bang around his ranch, which rambles for 10 miles beside the Mexico line. One’s a red Chevy that not long ago carried the body of yet another border crosser who had died on his property. The other is a blue Dodge with better shocks, and that’s what he is driving now, along an unpaved road in an unincorporated place called Naco.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry

articles.headline: Elon Musk of Tesla Sticks to Mission Despite Setbacks
articles.snippet: The billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk is running a private rocket company, doubling down on alternative fuels and pressing on with Tesla after a series of accidents.
articles.abstract: The billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk is running a private rocket company, doubling down on alternative fuels and pressing on with Tesla after a series of accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla Motors, sat in a glass-walled conference room here last week in the company’s auto factory. Around him, workers and robots were building the $70,000 luxury vehicles that have redefined how people think about electric cars.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Years Before Truck Rampage in Nice, Attacker Wasn’t ‘Living in the Real World’
articles.snippet: Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people in France, had long displayed a propensity for violence, and his life appears to show how the unstable have latched on to Islamic State propaganda.
articles.abstract: Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people in France, had long displayed a propensity for violence, and his life appears to show how the unstable have latched on to Islamic State propaganda.
articles.lead_paragraph: MSAKEN, Tunisia — His own parents were so frightened by his violence that they kicked him out when he was 16. Desperate, by the time he was 19, they dragged him to a psychiatrist, who prescribed an antipsychotic drug, a tranquilizer and an antidepressant.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter, Alissa J. Rubin and Lilia Blaise

articles.headline: Yahoo’s Sale to Verizon Ends an Era for a Web Pioneer
articles.snippet: It’s the end of the line for Yahoo as an independent company, once valued at $125 billion.
articles.abstract: It’s the end of the line for Yahoo as an independent company, once valued at $125 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo was the front door to the web for an early generation of internet users, and its services still attract a billion visitors a month.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Debbie Wasserman Schultz to Resign D.N.C. Post
articles.snippet: Some prominent Democrats had called for the Democratic National Committee chairwoman to step down in the wake of emails revealing the party’s attempts to undermine Bernie Sanders’s presidential bid.
articles.abstract: Some prominent Democrats had called for the Democratic National Committee chairwoman to step down in the wake of emails revealing the party’s attempts to undermine Bernie Sanders’s presidential bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Covention.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Planned Parenthood Turns to Tumblr to Reach a Younger Audience
articles.snippet: In a departure from traditional marketing, the organization’s 100th anniversary ad campaign features personal stories of patients, staff and volunteers.
articles.abstract: In a departure from traditional marketing, the organization’s 100th anniversary ad campaign features personal stories of patients, staff and volunteers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it undertakes an ad campaign in celebration of its 100th anniversary, Planned Parenthood of New York City is trying to reach a younger generation with a message about sexual and reproductive health. That message does not shy away from what one expert in nonprofit marketing called “the elephant in the room” — abortion.
articles.byline: By Martha C. White

articles.headline: Researchers Who Exposed VW Gain Little Reward From Success
articles.snippet: The team, at West Virginia University, often scrounges for grants. That financial pressure is unlikely to dissipate, despite uncovering the emissions fraud.
articles.abstract: The team, at West Virginia University, often scrounges for grants. That financial pressure is unlikely to dissipate, despite uncovering the emissions fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — The scientific detective work that forced Volkswagen into a $15 billion settlement began with a handful of researchers armed with just $70,000.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: How Sponsored Content Is Becoming King in a Facebook World
articles.snippet: As native advertising gains prominence, publishers may find themselves competing not just with one another, but with the ad agencies that already exist.
articles.abstract: As native advertising gains prominence, publishers may find themselves competing not just with one another, but with the ad agencies that already exist.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some publishers unsettled by a fast-changing online advertising business, sponsored content has provided much-needed relief.
articles.byline: By John Herrman

articles.headline: As Democrats Gather, a Russian Subplot Raises Intrigue
articles.snippet: Researchers have concluded that the Democratic National Committee was breached by two Russian intelligence agencies, and metadata from the released emails suggests that the documents passed through Russian computers.
articles.abstract: Researchers have concluded that the Democratic National Committee was breached by two Russian intelligence agencies, and metadata from the released emails suggests that the documents passed through Russian computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
